EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

NORTH COUNTY REGIONAL WATER TREATMENT PLANT

RMP SUBMITTAL JANUARY 2007



Accidental Release and prevention and emergency response policy:

It is the policy of the Collier County Water Department to operate safe reliable water treatment facilities, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the treatment process and the chemicals required as part of that process.  It is also the policy of the Collier County Water Department to work with surrounding community and local emergency response agencies, and promote a spirit of cooperation and teamwork to provide an effective contingency plan in the event that a process incident occurs at the North County Regional Water Treatment Plant (NCRWTP).    The first responder to any incident at the NCRWTP is the Golden Gate Fire Department (GGFD).  The GGFD works in close relation with the NCRWTP being involved in annual reviews of the RMP documentation and frequent training sessions on site for the GGFD personnel.



Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

The primary activity at the NCRWTP is a municipal water treatment plant.  Chlorine is the only 40 CFR 68 regulated substance at plant.  Chlorine is used primarily as a disinfectant.  The maximum amount of chlorine on site at this facility is 24 tons.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Collier County is in compliance with 40 CFR 68. The County has conducted a comprehensive review of the chlorine system, as well as, administrative, technical, operating, and maintenance procedures.  In addition, all program elements have been reviewed by the County?s internal safety auditors (Risk Management Department) and found to be in compliance.



The County has both passive mitigation, an enclosed building and active mitigation, an emergency scrubber, to minimize the consequences of an accidental release.  The Risk Management Program addresses actions to minimize the lik

elihood of an accidental release and minimize the impact if one was to occur.



Five Year Accident History:

There was no incidents in the last five years at the NCRWTP that involved exposure to anyone onsite or release of chlorine.



Emergency Response Program:

The NCRWTP has an emergency response program that is coordinated with the Collier County Comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that has been prepared in accordance with all local, state, and federal regulations.  The ERP for the NCRWTP specifically is attached to the RMP document as Attachment A to Chapter 9.







Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

As part of the Process Hazard Analysis that was conducted in 1999 a number of safety improvements were contemplated, the following provides a list of the items identified and steps taken to resolve each item:



To be completed by August 1999

To minimize the potential for product delivery trucks from damaging the buildings, equipment and roadway, improvements to the roadway must be made.  This work is current in progress.

Outcome:  Bumpers were installed in December of 1999 and the loading area was widened in early 2000.  This issue is closed.



Chlorine containers must be rotated in the trunnions to properly align the valves prior to connection.  The wrench currently used is not adequate and procurement of this specialized wrench is recommended.

Outcome:  Wrench was obtained in 1999 and one is kept on hand at all times. This issue is closed.



The wrenches used to connect/disconnect chlorine containers are the proper Chlorine Institute approved wrenches; however, they are old and worn.  Replacement wrenches should be purchased, and spare wrenches kept in stock.

Outcome:  Wrenches were obtained in August of 1999 and spares are on the shelf as of this review.  This issue is closed.



Request Standard Operating Procedures for truck unloading and certification that the chlorine meets AWWA specifications from the chlorine supplier.  Inform plan pers

onnel so that staff is familiar with the supplier?s safety and operating procedures.

Outcome:  Standard Operating Procedure for handling loading and unloading was completed in January of 2007 and reviewed.  Vendor requested to provide updates at minimum annually.  The Purchasing Department has been provided additional requirements in the bid specifications in order to ensure compliance with AWWA specifications. This issue is closed.



Due to the chemical nature of chlorine, any work performed in the chlorine areas that involves heat or sparks should be closely monitored.  Hot work permitting should be implemented.

Outcome:  Hot Work Permits have been initiated. This form is part of the Risk Management Plan.  Refresher training is conducted periodically regarding this policy. This issue is closed.



There is a danger that visitors or other untrained individuals may enter chlorine areas, which is a potential risk.  Signs should be posted in the chlorine storage areas to designate it as a restricted area.

Outcome:  Signage has been updated and improved to state only authorized personnel in this area and additional cameras have been put in the area to monitor for unauthorized personnel in the area.  All work was completed in 2004. This issue is closed.



Proper use and maintenance of respirators is critical. A program for employees that wear respirators should include medical exams, fit testing and training.  Purchase spare parts for respirators.

Outcome:  This is an on-going item.  As new team members are hired the Human Resources Department as part of the initial fitness for duty physical incorporates the respirator physicals.  After that annual check-ups are completed by the Occupational Nurse on staff with Collier County. Spare parts are kept on hand for all respirators both onsite and in the Department?s central warehouse. This issue is closed.



Develop an emergency evacuation plan for plant personnel.  The evacuation plan should include two egress routes

and designate a location for staff members to reassemble.

Outcome:  An evacuation plan has been developed and is reviewed annually with all team members.  The Plan is provided to new team members as part of their new hire orientation. This issue is closed.



The monorail used to move chlorine containers has a potential of sticking in place.  The monorail should be lubricated with material that is compatible with chlorine use. 

Outcome:  The Water Department has a semi-annual maintenance contract with an outside vendor that requires this to be completed.  A report is provided to the Department and kept on file documenting that it has been completed. This issue is closed.







To be completed by October 1999

There is a potential danger that the door to the building could shut while off-loading chlorine containers.  This could lead to dropping the container, causing possible injury to the employee, or otherwise compromising the integrity of the container. A door security system should be installed.

Outcome: The door security should be installed and the potential for the door to close has been eliminated.  The work was completed in 2005. This issue is closed.



To be completed by November 1999

The existing vacuum regulators are old and require constant maintenance.  It is recommended that the regulators at this facility be replaced by November 1999 or earlier.

Outcome:  The recommended work was completed in 1999 and as noted above a semi-annual contract is in place to ensure proper inspection and maintenance of the equipment is an ongoing effort. This issue is closed.



A preventative maintenance and replacement plan should be developed and implemented for the vacuum regulators. Plugs should be utilized to prevent moisture and dirt from entering the vacuum regulators when they are stored or immediately after servicing.

Outcome:  The recommended preventative maintenance plan has been implemented since 1999 and continues.  There is a semi-annual maintenance co

ntract for the work to be completed; in addition an automated maintenance software package is utilized to track the necessary replacements ? AllMax. This issue is closed.



A spare vacuum regulator should be purchased to enable continued operation while awaiting container pickup.

Outcome:  The spare vacuum regulator was purchased in 1999 and one is kept in spare at all times. This issue is closed.



An annual preventative maintenance program for the entire chlorine system should be prepared and implemented. The preventative maintenance program should include the following equipment:  Valves on the solution line; injector check valve; pressure gauges on water or chlorine solution line; flexible tubing from chlorine container to header; pvc piping and replace all gaskets and washers when servicing chlorinator.

Outcome:  The recommended preventative maintenance plan has been implemented since 1999 and continues.  There is a semi-annual maintenance contract for the work to be completed; in addition an automated maintenance software package is utilized to track the necessary replacements ? AllMax. This issue is closed.



There are currently many false alarms regarding chlorine releases, which lead to a tendency to disregard the alarms as likely to be false. An evaluation of the system and an established plan should be implemented by November 1999.

Outcome:  The system has been evaluated and the facility?s process software was upgraded in 2005 which eliminated this problem.  This issue is closed.  





The chlorine detectors and alarm system should be placed on an uninterruptible power supply (UPS) to eliminate false alarms due to power outages.

Outcome:  The chlorine detectors and alarm system are on the facility uninterruptible power supply (UPS). The UPS was upgraded in 2006 and is tested periodically to ensure proper working order.  This issue is closed.



Degradation of the PVC piping in the chlorine system occurs over time and it should be replaced every fi

ve to seven years. An evaluation of the piping should be made by November 1999 and a replacement scheduled implemented accordingly.

Outcome:  There is an overall renewal and replacement capital program in place for the Plant and this is an element of that Plan.  Additionally, there is an automated maintenance tracking system and this is an item plugged into that system.  This issue is closed.



To be completed by January 2000

High speed vertical lifting of chlorine containers is not part of standard operations, however, it is available and there is a risk of accidental use. The high speed vertical setting on the monorail mounted hoist should be disconnected, if possible.

Outcome:  This recommendation was discussed with the monorail manufacture who states that there is no hazard, as the high speed setting factors in the chlorine component and therefore does not move at rate to cause a problem.  Further the disconnecting of this one component of the system was not recommended and would have voided any warranty on the monorail system. This issue is closed.



There is a potential of a caustic gas release in an unsafe manner from the exhaust stack. This is due to an inadequate rain cap.  The rain cap should be modified or replaced.

Outcome: The rain cap has been reviewed by the Public Utilities Engineering Department, plant personnel, the equipment manufacturer and supplier. The existing original equipment is appropriate for this application. This issue is closed. 



The current location of the header vacuum gauge and valves is a trip hazard. The header should be moved to a safer location to avoid potential falls, which could result in leakage at a valve.  

Outcome:  Potential modifications are being reviewed. This issue remains open.



Complete modifications of the chlorine system alarms to minimize false alarms.

Outcome:  The software upgrade completed in 2005 resulted in the resolution of this matter.  This issue is closed.   



Consider providing position

switches on normal ventilation dampers to notify plant personnel of a failure to close during scrubber operation.

Outcome:  The scrubber system has a number of alarms that cover this type of event.  No further modifications were needed to be performed.  This issue is closed.



Several non-chlorine lines in the chlorine room are painted the same color as the chlorine lines. Labeling and piping colors should be modified to be consistent with County or other recognized standards.

Outcome:  All piping within the area was repainted in 2004 to come into compliance with AWWA Standards.   This issue is closed.



There is a potential for a motorized switch over system to fail during transfer of chlorine containers in the scales. The motorized switch over system should be replaced with a pressure operated system switch over system or the system should be manually operated.

Outcome:  In 2000, a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) was formulated to address this issue.  The SOP is now part of the updated Risk Management Plan.  This issue is closed.



To be completed by October 2000

The monorail system used to off-load chlorine containers requires that the containers eventually be rolled to their destination. The monorail system should be modified to allow off-loading of chlorine containers without rolling or implement a system that does not require rolling.

Outcome: The vendor who now supplies chlorine utilizes a cherry-picker to off load the cylinders thus this issues does not come into play.  The vendor is Harcoss/Allied.  In the bid specifications, for future vendors a sentence has been inserted that states that the vendor must have bring the proper equipment onsite to avoid having to roll the containers to their location.  This issue is closed.



To be completed by January 2001

The pressure relief valve will currently release chlorine gas to the room.  The pressure relief valve should be configured so that released gas is directed to the chlorine scrubber. An alarm

should be provided for the pressure relief system. The alarm should initiate start of the scrubber and notify plant personnel after the event. 

Outcome:  A review of the system in 2001, found the existing system was constructed in accordance with approved plans. Periodic regulatory agency inspections indicate the system is operating as intended. This issue is closed.



Continued effort to reduce false alarms should include the elimination of gas releases to the atmosphere at the chlorine application point below the degasifers, which potentially trip the alarm system.

Outcome:  To date, facility efforts to reduce false alarms have been successful. Some minor venting of gas at the clear well application point is unavoidable.  This issue is closed.



Install cable securing system for all ton containers. Securing the containers will provide additional anchoring during hurricane or other severe weather events.

Outcome:  In 2004, additional anchoring has been installed and is utilized in preparation for major weather events.  This issue is closed.









In 2006 another PHA team was formed and again did a total review of all processes  involving the chlorine system and all elements of the RMP.  The following items remain from that effort: 



To be completed by January 2007

Provide local emergency responders with the revised RMP.



To be completed by February 2007

Write chlorine vendor to request all documentation of safety training that relates to off load and loading cylinders.



To be completed by March 2007

Provide updated awareness training to permit team regarding blasting restrictions in the area surrounding the Plant.  



To be completed by June of 2007

Procurement requires chlorine vendor to provide documentation of safety training for their team members.  Need to plug past history performance into purchasing process.



Develop Job Safety Analysis (JSA) in addition to existing standard operating procedure for offloading and loading cylinders, be su

re it addresses chalking of cylinders, ergonomics (body mechanics), and crane inspection/operation.



Install additional Wind Sox so one can be seen while standing at all areas from the ground on plant property.



To be completed by August 2007

Conduct 8HRs of HAZMAT Scenario training for all hazardous materials potential releases including chlorine and terrorist acts and community notification.  Work with local emergency responders to establish a notification protocol outcome to be done by August 2007.



To be completed by end of 2007

The current location of the header vacuum gauge and valves is a trip hazard. The header should be moved to a safer location to avoid potential falls, which could result in leakage at a valve.  



To be completed by end of 2008

Review the ability to install a second egress route from the chlorine room.  Will be reviewed as part of overall upgrade of existing chemical feed system for NCRWTP expansion to occur in 2008.   



Contract 3rd Party Engineer to perform an updated vulnerability assessment now that all items in previous assessment have been completed.
